g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Challenges to governing innovation for sustainable development
Dominant economic systems and centralized governance structures conti
patterns of production and consumption, reinforcing many economic and governance structures from
local through national and global scales
(See also Section 5.6 in Chapter 5, and Chapter
oriented technological transformations require at a minimum
balanced views and new tools for se
curing the scientific legitimacy and credibility to connect public
policy and technological change in our society
been proposed, such as reflexive governance
A particular class of barriers to the development and adoption of new technologies comprises
entrenched power relations dominated by vested interests that control and benefit from existing
technological regimes that are related to technological lock
allocations of investment between fossil and renewable energy technologies
plementation capacity in some developing countries can undermine ability
offs with other development objectives, like reinforced inequalities or excessive
indebtedness and increased external dependency, and can limit the potential of leverag
benefits from technologies transferred from abroad (Section 16.5, Cross
income setting the exclusion of some local stakeholders from the
sustainability transitions efforts. Countries with high levels of
inequality can be more prone to elite capture, non
relations based on clientelism and patronage, and no independent judiciary
dominance of incumbents however implies that sustainable technological transitions could be achieved
without yielding any social and democratic benefits
recurrent policy challenge that has been observed in most countries is the limited public support for
development and deployment of low carbon technologies
conventional approach to mobilizing such support has been to portray technological change as a means
cal studies show that simply reframing climate policy is highly
unlikely to build and sustain public support
Finally, there is a link between social and technological innovation; any innovation is grounded in
economic arrangements, to which governance arrangements would need to respond (see
in this chapter). Social innovation can
contribute to maximizing synergies and minimizing trade
offs in relation to technological innovation
and other innovative practices, but for this to materialize, national, regional and local
need to be taken into account and, if needed, changed. Even in circumstances of high capabilities, the
extent social innovation might help to promote synergies and avoid trade
offs is not easy to evaluate
